meanings.def: damage or injury that is caused by a person or an event
examples: He would never frighten anyone or cause them any harm.
The accused clearly intended to inflict harm on him.
He may look fierce, but he means no harm.
harm to somebody/something No definite harm to human health has been determined.
The court case will do serious harm to my business.
The accident could have been much worse; luckily no harm was done.
Don't worry, we'll see that the children come to no harm.
I can't say I like Mark very much, but I don't wish him any harm.
Hard work never did anyone any harm.
Look, we're just going out for a few drinks, where's the harm in that?
The treatment they gave him did him more harm than good.
I don't think he'll come to any harm if his mother is with him.
I don't want any harm to come to these pictures.
I'm sorry if I upset you—I didn't mean any harm.
She tried to shield her child from harm.
The children were removed from their parents to prevent harm to them.
babies at risk of serious harm from their parents
elderly people in danger of physical or emotional harm
The region will suffer substantial economic harm as a result of this decision.

meanings.def: used to suggest that it would be a good idea for somebody to do something
examples: It wouldn't do you any harm to smarten yourself up.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody not to worry because they have caused no serious damage or injury
examples: Forget it, Dave, no harm done.

meanings.def: in a safe place where somebody/something cannot be hurt or injured or do any damage to somebody/something
examples: She put the knife in a drawer, out of harm’s way.
I prefer the children to play in the garden where they’re out of harm’s way.

meanings.def: used to tell somebody that something is a good idea and will not cause any problems
examples: He may say no, but there's no harm in asking.
It does no harm to ask.

idioms.idiom: it wouldn’t do somebody any harm (to do something)
idioms.def: used to suggest that it would be a good idea for somebody to do something
examples: It wouldn't do you any harm to smarten yourself up.

idioms.def: used to tell somebody not to worry because they have caused no serious damage or injury
examples: Forget it, Dave, no harm done.

idioms.def: in a safe place where somebody/something cannot be hurt or injured or do any damage to somebody/something
examples: She put the knife in a drawer, out of harm’s way.
I prefer the children to play in the garden where they’re out of harm’s way.

idioms.idiom: there is no harm in (somebody’s) doing something | it does no harm (for somebody) to do something
idioms.def: used to tell somebody that something is a good idea and will not cause any problems
examples: He may say no, but there's no harm in asking.
It does no harm to ask.

related: not harm/touch a hair of somebody’s head

meanings.def: to hurt or injure somebody or to damage something
examples: He would never harm anyone.
Pollution can harm marine life.
These revelations will harm her chances of winning the election.
Rising oil prices could harm the global economy.
It's important to grow the business in a way that does not harm the environment.
Misusing drugs in pregnancy can seriously harm your baby.
The decision could harm British interests.
The country's treatment of asylum seekers is harming its international reputation.
He claimed that he had not intended to harm the girl.
The fire badly damaged the town hall.
emotionally damaged children
Hard work never hurt anyone.
Pollution can harm marine life.
Even one drink can impair driving performance.

meanings.def: to be kind and gentle and unwilling to cause unhappiness
to not hurt somebody physically in any way

idioms.def: to be kind and gentle and unwilling to cause unhappiness

idioms.idiom: not harm/touch a hair of somebody’s head
idioms.def: to not hurt somebody physically in any way
